title: 106_hr5469
content: The Act titled "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act within 30 days if misconduct, bias, serious conflict of interest, departure from procedure, or exceeding of powers is alleged. The appeal can be filed with the United States Court of International Trade if the panel's actions materially affect the decision and threaten the review process integrity. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act within 30 days if misconduct, bias, serious conflict of interest, departure from procedure, or exceeding of powers is alleged. An appeal can be filed with the United States Court of International Trade if the panel's actions materially affect the decision and threaten the review process integrity. The Court of International Trade will examine the legal and factual analysis underlying the panel's decision and determine if any actions described have been established. If so, the original panel decision will be vacated, and judgment entered accordingly. The Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction over appeals related to binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. Decisions made by the Court are binding on the parties involved. This section applies to goods from NAFTA countries subject to antidumping or countervailing duty determinations in the United States. The Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction over appeals related to binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. This section applies to goods from NAFTA countries subject to antidumping or countervailing duty determinations in the United States. SEC. 3. JURISDICTION OF THE COURT OF INTERNATIONAL TRADE. Section 516A of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include provisions related to binational panel decisions under NAFTA. This section applies to goods from NAFTA countries subject to antidumping or countervailing duty determinations in the United States. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include provisions for binational panel decisions under NAFTA, specifically regarding requests for review under section 404A of the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The amendments made by this Act apply to final determinations of binational panels under NAFTA published in the Federal Register after the enactment date.
